item.title: Splurge Day: When Treating Yourself Became a Holiday
item.itunes:title: Splurge Day: When Treating Yourself Became a Holiday
item.description:
From Black Friday bargains to mindful money moments, National Splurge Day celebrates the art of intentional indulgence. Created in 1994 by Chicago's Adrienne Sioux Koopersmith, America's Premier Eventologist, this holiday transforms guilt-free spending into a form of self-care. The day's origin traces back to Koopersmith's vision of legitimizing occasional treats without the accompanying remorse. From the historic 1991 Macy's Herald Square diamond necklace frenzy to modern luxury purchases, the celebration emphasizes mindful indulgence over reckless spending. Research suggests that planned splurges can actually enhance long-term financial discipline, similar to scheduled cheat days in dieting. Today's retailers honor the occasion with exclusive deals, offering up to 25% discounts on premium items and special restaurant experiences. Whether it's concert tickets, gourmet dining, or that long-desired purchase, National Splurge Day encourages participants to invest in experiences and items that spark genuine joy, staying true to Koopersmith's original vision of meaningful self-investment.
Learn More: • 'History Podcasts That Will Make You Rethink Everything' (https://wondery.com/news/10-history-podcasts-that-will-make-you-rethink-everything-you-think-you-know/) • 'The Holiday Industrial Complex - Planet Money Episode' (https://www.npr.org/transcripts/524577372) • 'Meet the People Behind Wacky Holidays' (https://www.cnn.com/2018/02/26/us/wacky-holidays-who-creates-them-trnd) • 'National Splurge Day History and Celebration Guide' (https://www.nationaldayarchives.com/day/national-splurge-day/)
Note: This content was generated using artificial intelligence and may contain factual errors or inaccuracies. Please verify any important information from reliable sources.

item.title: From Victory Gardens to Veggie Victories: America's Green Revolution
item.itunes:title: From Victory Gardens to Veggie Victories: America's Green Revolution
item.description:
Explore the fascinating history and modern significance of National Eat Your Vegetables Day, tracing its roots to the Victory Gardens of World War II when Americans produced an astounding 40% of the nation's vegetables in their backyards. Officially recognized in 1996 by the Center for Science in the Public Interest, this celebration addresses the ongoing challenge of vegetable consumption in American diets. The episode delves into the science behind vegetable aversion, revealing that 25% of people are "super tasters" who experience bitter flavors more intensely. In 2025, the holiday has evolved into a nationwide movement, with farmers' markets hosting cooking demonstrations to transform traditionally unpopular vegetables like Brussels sprouts into delectable dishes. The Council for Retirement Security's "Eat the Rainbow at Any Age" campaign emphasizes the crucial role of colorful vegetables in brain health and longevity. From the historical significance of Victory Gardens producing over 8 million tons of food to modern cooking innovations, this episode offers practical tips for discovering new ways to enjoy vegetables, reminding listeners that taste preferences change every seven years.
Learn More: • The Jillian Michaels Show - "Can We Use Food to Fix Our DNA?" (https://wondery.com/shows/the-jillian-michaels-show/episode/5612-can-we-use-food-to-fix-our-dna/) • "Victory Gardens: Food for the Fight" (https://www.nationalww2museum.org/war/articles/victory-gardens-world-war-ii) • "The Modern Victory Garden - Book" (https://www.amazon.com/Modern-Victory-Garden-Self-Sufficiency-Sustainability/dp/1735006505) • "Victory Garden at the National Museum of American History" (https://gardens.si.edu/gardens/victory-garden/)
Note: This content was generated using artificial intelligence and may contain factual errors or inaccuracies. Please verify any important information from reliable sources.

In 2025, the holiday has evolved into a nationwide movement, with farmers' markets hosting cooking demonstrations to transform traditionally unpopular vegetables like Brussels sprouts into delectable dishes. The Council for Retirement Security's "Eat the Rainbow at Any Age" campaign emphasizes the crucial role of colorful vegetables in brain health and longevity. From the historical significance of Victory Gardens producing over 8 million tons of food to modern cooking innovations, this episode offers practical tips for discovering new ways to enjoy vegetables, reminding listeners that taste preferences change every seven years.
